articles.headline: Can You Really Hire a Hit Man on the Dark Web?
articles.snippet: A collection of online stores offer murder for pay. Researchers say they are scams, but people who want someone dead aren’t listening.
articles.abstract: A collection of online stores offer murder for pay. Researchers say they are scams, but people who want someone dead aren’t listening.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — On a website called Azerbaijani Eagles, you can commission a murder for $5,000. The site Slayers Hitmen provides more options, with a beating going for $2,000. Death by torture costs $50,000.

articles.headline: We Spoke to Six Americans With Coronavirus
articles.snippet: It is one thing to be sick. It is another not to know your chances of getting well. Americans who have had the virus share their experiences.
articles.abstract: It is one thing to be sick. It is another not to know your chances of getting well. Americans who have had the virus share their experiences.
articles.lead_paragraph: Late one night, after a test confirmed the stealth invasion of his cells by the new coronavirus, Dale Grizzle was seized with a violent fit of vomiting in his hospital room.

articles.headline: DoorDash Faces Its Latest Challenge: Wooing Wall Street
articles.snippet: The food delivery app is losing money, battling rivals, facing lawsuits — and trying to go public. What could go wrong?
articles.abstract: The food delivery app is losing money, battling rivals, facing lawsuits — and trying to go public. What could go wrong?
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — DoorDash, the leading food delivery app in the United States, has its fans. Hungry people. Busy people. Lazy people.

articles.headline: With Oil Prices Down 20%, OPEC Pushes for Stability
articles.snippet: A meeting of oil ministers is trying to agree to cuts in output as the coronavirus outbreak slows economic activity.
articles.abstract: A meeting of oil ministers is trying to agree to cuts in output as the coronavirus outbreak slows economic activity.
articles.lead_paragraph: A 20 percent plunge in oil prices this year since the coronavirus outbreak took hold has alarmed the world’s top oil officials, and their challenge to prop up prices keeps getting harder.
articles.byline: By Stanley Reed and Clifford Krauss

articles.headline: Airlines Feel Deepening Impact as Coronavirus Upends Travel
articles.snippet: United will curtail service on domestic and global routes as companies restrict trips, testing a long stretch of airline industry profitability.
articles.abstract: United will curtail service on domestic and global routes as companies restrict trips, testing a long stretch of airline industry profitability.
articles.lead_paragraph: Since the financial crisis a decade ago, airlines in the United States have consolidated and tightened operations, taken advantage of changing travel habits and created new offerings for passengers, engineering an extended stretch of profitability.

articles.headline: Why Did Biden Suddenly Sweep Virginia? Credit Trump, These Voters Say
articles.snippet: Men and women, white people and black people, college graduates and non-graduates alike — all came together to propel Joe Biden to a resounding victory over Bernie Sanders.
articles.abstract: Men and women, white people and black people, college graduates and non-graduates alike — all came together to propel Joe Biden to a resounding victory over Bernie Sanders.
articles.lead_paragraph: FALLS CHURCH, Va. — They were disaffected Republicans in affluent Washington suburbs. They were shipyard employees in Norfolk. And they were health care workers in Petersburg.
articles.byline: By Reid J. Epstein and Stephanie Saul

articles.headline: A Global Outbreak Is Fueling the Backlash to Globalization
articles.snippet: As the coronavirus spreads around the world, companies are seeking alternatives to making goods in China, while right-wing political parties fulminate against open borders.
articles.abstract: As the coronavirus spreads around the world, companies are seeking alternatives to making goods in China, while right-wing political parties fulminate against open borders.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Well before a deadly virus began spreading across multiple borders, a world defined by deepening interconnection appeared to be reassessing the merits of globalization.

articles.headline: U.A.W. Corruption Case Widens as Former Chief Is Charged
articles.snippet: Gary Jones, the United Auto Workers leader until last fall, is accused of embezzlement. A prosecutor spoke of a previous U.S. takeover of a union as a model.
articles.abstract: Gary Jones, the United Auto Workers leader until last fall, is accused of embezzlement. A prosecutor spoke of a previous U.S. takeover of a union as a model.
articles.lead_paragraph: For five years, federal investigators have pieced together a broad pattern of corruption within the United Automobile Workers. They documented the diversion of dues for high living by union officials and found a conspiracy that may have compromised dealings with a leading automaker.
articles.byline: By Noam Scheiber and Neal E. Boudette

articles.headline: Workplace vs. Coronavirus: ‘No One Has a Playbook for This’
articles.snippet: The deadly disease has arrived in some offices, and employers are figuring out how to adapt.
articles.abstract: The deadly disease has arrived in some offices, and employers are figuring out how to adapt.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — At Facebook on Thursday, the questions from spooked employees came thick and fast.
articles.byline: By Mike Isaac, David Yaffe-Bellany and Karen Weise

articles.headline: Elizabeth Warren, Once a Front-Runner, Drops Out of Presidential Race
articles.snippet: Ms. Warren, a senator and former law professor, staked her campaign on fighting corruption and changing the rules of the economy.
articles.abstract: Ms. Warren, a senator and former law professor, staked her campaign on fighting corruption and changing the rules of the economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — Senator Elizabeth Warren entered the 2020 race with expansive plans to use the federal government to remake American society, pressing to strip power and wealth from a moneyed class that she saw as fundamentally corrupting the country’s economic and political order.
articles.byline: By Shane Goldmacher and Astead W. Herndon
